answer_html: \(\int x^2e^{2x}dx=\frac12 x^2e^{2x} - \frac12 xe^{2x} + \frac14 e^{2x} + c\)
hints_html: You can either try each case or try to guess what would happen if you tried each case without actually writing each.
hints_latex:
You can either try each case or try to guess what would happen if you
tried each case without actually writing each.
hints_raw: You can either try each case or try to guess what would happen if you tried each case without actually writing each.
question: 1 (b)
sols_html:
We want to integrate

\[\begin{aligned} \int x^2e^{2x}dx\end{aligned}\]

with integration by parts. We have three possible products:

a) \(1\cdot x^2e^{2x}\)

b) \(x\cdot xe^{2x}\)

c) \(x^2\cdot e^{2x}\)

The first product doesn’t make sense to choose since the second term is neither easy to derivate nor to integrate.

The second product also doesn’t make sense because the second term is not easy to integrate. Also choosing \(xe^{2x}\) as \(u\) and \(x\) as \(dv\) is not good since integrating \(x\) AND derivating \(xe^{2x}\) makes the equation more complicated.

So it must be the third product. It doesn’t matter, if we choose \(e^{2x}\) as \(u\) or \(dv\) because the integral is the same (excapt for constants). If we choose \(x^2\) as \(dv\), we get \(x^3/3\) as \(v\), what makes the equation more complicated. So we take \(x^2\) as \(u\) and get \(du=2x\) and \(e^{2x}\) \(dv\) and get \(v=e^{2x}/2\). That simplified the equation. So we take answer ii.

Integration would work now like this:

\[\begin{aligned} \int x^2e^{2x}dx &= \frac12 x^2e^{2x} - \int 2x\frac12 e^{2x}dx\\ &= \frac12 x^2e^{2x} - \underbrace{\int xe^{2x}dx}_{\text{integrate by parts again}}\\ &= \frac12 x^2e^{2x} - \frac12 xe^{2x} + \int\frac12 e^{2x}dx\\ &= \frac12 x^2e^{2x} - \frac12 xe^{2x} + \frac14 e^{2x} + c\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
We want to integrate

\begin{align*}
\int x^2e^{2x}dx
\end{align*} with integration by parts. We have three possible
products:

a) $1\cdot x^2e^{2x}$

b) $x\cdot xe^{2x}$

c) $x^2\cdot e^{2x}$

The first product doesn't make sense to choose since the second term is
neither easy to derivate nor to integrate.

The second product also doesn't make sense because the second term is
not easy to integrate. Also choosing $xe^{2x}$ as $u$ and $x$ as $dv$ is
not good since integrating $x$ AND derivating $xe^{2x}$ makes the
equation more complicated.

So it must be the third product. It doesn't matter, if we choose
$e^{2x}$ as $u$ or $dv$ because the integral is the same (excapt for
constants). If we choose $x^2$ as $dv$, we get $x^3/3$ as $v$, what
makes the equation more complicated. So we take $x^2$ as $u$ and get
$du=2x$ and $e^{2x}$ $dv$ and get $v=e^{2x}/2$. That simplified the
equation. \textbf{So we take answer ii.}

Integration would work now like this:

\begin{align*}
\int x^2e^{2x}dx &= \frac12 x^2e^{2x} - \int 2x\frac12 e^{2x}dx\\
 &= \frac12 x^2e^{2x} - \underbrace{\int xe^{2x}dx}_{\text{integrate by parts again}}\\
 &= \frac12 x^2e^{2x} - \frac12 xe^{2x} + \int\frac12 e^{2x}dx\\
 &= \frac12 x^2e^{2x} - \frac12 xe^{2x} + \frac14 e^{2x} + c
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
We want to integrate
:<math>
\int x^2e^{2x}dx
</math>
with integration by parts. We have three possible products:


a) <math> 1\cdot x^2e^{2x} </math>

b) <math> x\cdot xe^{2x} </math>

c) <math> x^2\cdot e^{2x} </math>


The first product doesn't make sense to choose since the second term is neither easy to derivate nor to integrate.

The second product also doesn't make sense because the second term is not easy to integrate. Also choosing <math> xe^{2x}</math> as <math>u </math> and <math>x </math> as <math>dv </math> is not good since integrating <math> x</math> AND derivating <math>xe^{2x} </math> makes the equation more complicated. 

So it must be the third product. It doesn't matter, if we choose <math>e^{2x} </math> as <math>u </math> or <math> dv</math> because the integral is the same (excapt for constants). If we choose <math>x^2 </math> as <math>dv </math>, we get <math>x^3/3 </math> as <math>v </math>, what makes the equation more complicated.
So we take <math>x^2 </math> as <math> u</math> and get <math> du=2x</math> and <math>e^{2x} </math> <math>dv </math> and get <math> v=e^{2x}/2</math>. That simplified the equation. '''So we take answer ii.'''

Integration would work now like this:

:<math>\begin{align}
\int x^2e^{2x}dx =& \frac12 x^2e^{2x} - \int 2x\frac12 e^{2x}dx\\
 =& \frac12 x^2e^{2x} - \underbrace{\int xe^{2x}dx}_{\text{integrate by parts again}}\\
 =& \frac12 x^2e^{2x} - \frac12 xe^{2x} + \int\frac12 e^{2x}dx\\
 =& \frac12 x^2e^{2x} - \frac12 xe^{2x} + \frac14 e^{2x} + c
\end{align}
</math>
statement_html:
Multiple Choice Question: Exactly ONE of the answers provided is correct. There is no partial credit in this questions.

To find the integral

\[\begin{aligned} \int x^2 e^{2x}\, dx\end{aligned}\]

using integration by parts, the best choice for u and dv in the first step would be

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{i.}\quad u=x, \ dv=xe^{2x}\,dx\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{ii.}\quad u=x^2, \ dv=e^{2x}\,dx\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{iii.}\quad u=xe^{2x}, \ dv=x\,dx\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{iv.}\quad u=e^{2x}, \ dv=x^2\,dx\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{v.}\quad u=x, \ dv=e^{2x}\,dx\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
''Multiple Choice Question: Exactly ONE of the answers provided is correct. There is no partial credit in this questions.''

To find the integral
:<math>
\int x^2 e^{2x}\, dx
</math>
using integration by parts, the best choice for ''u'' and ''dv'' in the first step would be

:<math>\mathbf{i.}\quad u=x, \ dv=xe^{2x}\,dx </math>   

:<math>\mathbf{ii.}\quad u=x^2, \ dv=e^{2x}\,dx </math>  

:<math>\mathbf{iii.}\quad u=xe^{2x}, \ dv=x\,dx </math>  

:<math>\mathbf{iv.}\quad u=e^{2x}, \ dv=x^2\,dx </math>  

:<math>\mathbf{v.}\quad u=x, \ dv=e^{2x}\,dx </math>
